summary: The NeuroReach VR system aims to improve stroke rehabilitation by training reach and grasp through mixed-reality tasks with multimodal feedback.
text: The system is designed as a proof-of-concept mixed-reality platform for stroke rehabilitation, focusing on improving selective muscle activation in the arms. It incorporates an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task to train reach and grasp. Visual, auditory, and haptic feedback mechanisms are integrated into the tasks to enhance user engagement and learning. The system utilizes a Quest 3S headset with Shared Spatial Anchors for its mixed-reality capabilities.

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

summary: Technical challenges in mixed-reality implementation, such as anchor drift and noisy tilt estimation, are being addressed through specific solutions to ensure system effectiveness.
text: Potential issues like anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support are identified as challenges in the mixed-reality implementation. Solutions include relocalizing anchors at the session start and applying low-pass filtering and debouncing to tilt estimation. These technical hurdles directly impact the system's ability to accurately guide users through tasks like pouring and tracing. Alternative approaches, such as using fiducials instead of anchors or omitting haptics, are considered if primary solutions prove insufficient.

citations.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0001: The evidence highlights several technical challenges related to mixed-reality implementation that could impact system usability and effectiveness. Evidence E2 details significant challenges in the mixed-reality implementation, including 'Anchor drift,' 'noisy tilt estimation,' and 'inconsistent haptic support.' These issues directly affect the core functionalities of the system, such as guiding users through pouring and tracing tasks. If anchors drift, the virtual elements may not align correctly with the real environment, and noisy tilt estimation could lead to inaccurate feedback. Inconsistent haptic support would diminish the multimodal feedback crucial for an intuitive and motivational experience. The proposed solutions like 'Relocalize anchors at session start' and 'low pass tilt and debounce events' are mentioned, but their efficacy in a real-world rehabilitation setting with stroke patients is not yet demonstrated.

summary: The NeuroReach VR system features an adaptive controller designed to adjust task difficulty and feedback based on user performance, with mechanisms to mitigate oscillations and drift.
text: The adaptive controller is rule-based, adjusting elements like the corridor, tilt window, and tracing tunnel. Feedback gradually shifts from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results as the user progresses. Challenges such as overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions are acknowledged. Solutions like moving averages with gates and floors, along with buffered asynchronous writes, are proposed to address these adaptive control issues.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

citations.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0001: The evidence does not specify how the system will address the challenges of overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions. The claim states the system aims to improve selective muscle activation for stroke rehabilitation. However, evidence E1 outlines challenges in Work Package 3, specifically 'Overreactive difficulty oscillation' and 'metric drift across sessions.' While solutions like 'Moving average with gates and floors' are mentioned, it's unclear if these solutions are sufficient or fully developed to guarantee a stable and effective rehabilitation experience, which is crucial for stroke patients who may have varying recovery rates and sensitivities.

citations.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0002: The claim describes adaptive difficulty and fading feedback, but the evidence only partially details the adaptive controller's functions. The claim (c0002) asserts that the system will observe real-time adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on user muscle activation [E2], and that the adaptive controller will adjust the corridor, tilt window, and tracing tunnel based on performance, fading feedback from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results [E3]. Evidence E2 mentions 'adaptive difficulty' and 'fading feedback' as outcomes. However, the specific mechanisms of how the controller adjusts 'corridor', 'tilt window', and 'tracing tunnel' based on 'performance' and the transition from 'knowledge of performance' to 'knowledge of results' are not fully elaborated in the provided snippets. The evidence does not explicitly link muscle activation to the adaptive difficulty or feedback fading.

citations.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0003: The claim mentions 'noisy tilt estimation' and suggests low-pass filtering as a solution, but the evidence discusses 'metric drift across sessions' and proposes 'moving average with gates and floors' as a solution, which is a different approach. The claim (E4) identifies 'noisy tilt estimation' as a potential challenge and proposes 'low-pass filtering' as a solution. However, evidence E1, which also discusses challenges and solutions, mentions 'metric drift across sessions' as a challenge and suggests 'moving average with gates and floors' as a solution. While both relate to data smoothing, 'metric drift' is a broader issue than just noisy tilt estimation, and 'moving average with gates and floors' is a more complex solution than simple low-pass filtering. It's unclear if these are addressing the same underlying problem or different ones.

summary: A projected dashboard will provide real-time performance metrics and feedback, contributing to the system's motivational and clinical application potential.
text: The system includes a projected dashboard that displays key performance indicators updated per trial. Metrics shown on the dashboard include 'on path,' 'tilt window,' 'spills proxy,' and potentially 'RMS error' and 'SPARC'. The dashboard allows for observation of real-time adaptive difficulty and fading feedback mechanisms. The intuitiveness of feedback and the gamified environment are highlighted as factors contributing to the system's motivational aspect and potential for clinical use.

IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

citations.chunk_text: Challenge on claim c0002: The claim mentions a projected dashboard with specific metrics, but the evidence only partially supports this by listing some of those metrics. The claim (c0002) states that a projected dashboard will display metrics such as 'on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error, and SPARC', updated per trial. Evidence E1 mentions 'on path, time in tilt window, spill proxy' as being computed. Evidence E2 mentions 'on path, tilt window and spill proxy' as outcomes of the pouring task and 'tracing with tunnel and live error' for the tracing task. However, 'RMS error' and 'SPARC' are not explicitly mentioned in the provided evidence snippets. Therefore, the completeness of the dashboard's metrics as described in the claim is not fully substantiated.
